maml:description.maml:para: Disable a network interface.
Disable a network interface.

maml:Description.maml:para: A list of computer names as comma separated list.
File with a list of target computers.
Use an existing PSSession to execute the commands.
Alternate credentials to use.
Interface index number to search for.
Search string for interface description (also regex possible).
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
If multiple network interfaces were found disable them all. Otherwise, the script aborts.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.
Method to use by the function.
Check if the target hosts are online. Disabling it speeds things up.
File with a list of target computers.
A list of computer names as comma separated list.
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
Alternate credentials to use.
If multiple network interfaces were found disable them all. Otherwise, the script aborts.
Search string for interface description (also regex possible).
Interface index number to search for.
Use an existing PSSession to execute the commands.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.
Method to use by the function.
Check if the target hosts are online. Disabling it speeds things up.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code:
PS> Get-NetworkInterface -InterfaceDescription "intel"
Time : 19.01.2017 11:58:04 Function : Get-NetworkInterface ComputerName : localhost Arguments : InterfaceIndex: , InterfaceDescription: intel, OnlyIndex: False, OnlineCheck: True Status : pass Reason : {...}

dev:remarks.maml:para: Search for interfaces on the localhost of which its description contains "intel".

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 2 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code:
PS> Get-NetworkInterface -InterfaceDescription ".*wireless.*"
Time : 19.01.2017 11:58:04 Function : Get-NetworkInterface ComputerName : localhost Arguments : InterfaceIndex: , InterfaceDescription: .*wireless.*, OnlyIndex: False, OnlineCheck: True Status : pass Reason : {...}

dev:remarks.maml:para: Search for interfaces on the localhost of which its description contains the regex ". wireless. ".

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 3 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code:
PS> Get-NetworkInterface -ComputerName comp1 -InterfaceIndex 7
Time : 19.01.2017 12:01:59 Function : Get-NetworkInterface ComputerName : comp1 Arguments : InterfaceIndex: 7, InterfaceDescription: , OnlyIndex: False, OnlineCheck: True Status : pass Reason : {Index: 7...}

dev:remarks.maml:para: Search for interfaces of which its index is 7 on the remote host comp1.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 4 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code:
PS> Get-NetworkInterface -ComputerName comp1 -Credential $creds -InterfaceDescription ".*"
Time : 19.01.2017 12:04:28 Function : Get-NetworkInterface ComputerName : comp1 Arguments : InterfaceIndex: , InterfaceDescription: .*, OnlyIndex: False, OnlineCheck: True Status : pass Reason : {...}

dev:remarks.maml:para: List every interface from the remote host comp1 and use alternate credentials ("Get-Credential").

maml:description.maml:para: Disable a scheduled task.
The Disable-ScheduledTask cmdlet lets you disable a Windows scheduled task.
When no target host is supplied, localhost is used.
You have to supply the full task name (when not in root also the path to the task). Use `Get-ScheduledTask` to find the corresponding taskname.

maml:Description.maml:para: Binary path for using with external tools.
File with a list of target computers.
A list of computer names as comma separated list.
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
Alternate credentials to use.
Use an existing PSSession to execute the commands.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.
Do not enable RemoteRegistry. By default, if needed, RemoteRegistry will be enabled before running commands and disabled afterwards.
Method to use by the function.
Check if the target hosts are online. Disabling it speeds things up.
Search string to search for tasks. Use regex for matching.
Binary path for using with external tools.
File with a list of target computers.
A list of computer names as comma separated list.
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
Alternate credentials to use.
Use an existing PSSession to execute the commands.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.
Do not enable RemoteRegistry. By default, if needed, RemoteRegistry will be enabled before running commands and disabled afterwards.
Method to use by the function.
Check if the target hosts are online. Disabling it speeds things up.
Search string to search for tasks. Use regex for matching.

command:example.maml:title: ------------ Example 1: Disabling task on localhost ------------
command:example.dev:code:
PS> Disable-ScheduledTask -TaskName "Adobe Flash Player Updater" -UseExternal | ft
Time Action ComputerName Arguments Status Reason ---- ------ ------------ --------- ------ ------ 05.01.2017 20:37:08 Enable-Service localhost ServiceName: RemoteRegistry, StartupType: manual pass RemoteRegistry enabled. 05.01.2017 20:37:08 Edit-Service localhost ServiceName: RemoteRegistry, ServiceState start pass Service set to start. 05.01.2017 20:37:09 Stop-Service localhost ServiceName: RemoteRegistry pass Service set to stop. 05.01.2017 20:37:10 Disable-Service localhost ServiceName: RemoteRegistry pass Service disabled 05.01.2017 20:37:10 Edit-ScheduledTask localhost TaskName: "Adobe Flash Player Updater", TaskState: disable pass Task set to disable

dev:remarks.maml:para: You can combine the output of this cmdlet with the output of the other cmdlets.

command:example.maml:title: --------- Example 2: Disabling task on multiple hosts ---------
command:example.dev:code:
PS> Disable-ScheduledTask -TaskName "Adobe Flash Player Updater" -ComputerName Comp1, Comp2 -UseExternal | ft
Time Action ComputerName Arguments Status Reason ---- ------ ------------ --------- ------ ------ 05.01.2017 20:39:48 Enable-RemoteRegistry Comp1 fail offline 05.01.2017 20:39:51 Edit-Service Comp1 ServiceName: RemoteRegistry, ServiceState start fail offline 05.01.2017 20:39:51 Edit-ScheduledTask Comp1 TaskName: "Adobe Flash Player Updater", TaskState: disable fail Error while enabling RemoteRegistry 05.01.2017 20:39:53 Enable-RemoteRegistry Comp2 fail offline 05.01.2017 20:39:55 Edit-Service Comp2 ServiceName: RemoteRegistry, ServiceState start fail offline 05.01.2017 20:39:55 Edit-ScheduledTask Comp2 TaskName: "Adobe Flash Player Updater", TaskState: disable fail Error while enabling RemoteRegistry

dev:remarks.maml:para: Disables the tasks on multiple hosts and lists the progress of the whole chain.

maml:description.maml:para: Collect Autoruns output.
Collect Autoruns output with Sysinternal's Autorunsc. The CSV will be stored in the current directory by default and the computer name is used as filename.

maml:Description.maml:para: A list of computer names as comma separated list.
File with a list of target computers.
Output path for autoruns CSV file. If not specified, current directory is used. The CSV file will have the filename according to the target name.
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
Do not enable RemoteRegistry. By default, if needed, RemoteRegistry will be enabled before running commands and disabled afterwards.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.
{{Fill FilenamePostfix Description}}
File with a list of target computers.
A list of computer names as comma separated list.
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
Do not enable RemoteRegistry. By default, if needed, RemoteRegistry will be enabled before running commands and disabled afterwards.
Output path for autoruns CSV file. If not specified, current directory is used. The CSV file will have the filename according to the target name.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.
{{Fill FilenamePostfix Description}}

dev:remarks.maml:para: Collects Autoruns output from comp1 and stores CSV into current dir.

maml:description.maml:para: Find processes based on the on user supplied pid or process name information. Use regex for finding based on patterns.

The Get-Process function finds processes on the target machine based on the -Pid or -SearchString parameters. It also searches the executable path if available. This allows search for processes started from e.g. AppData.
By default WMI is used for quering the information. You can also use the method ( -method ) "external" for using pslist.
Use the parameter -Credential to supply different credentials.

maml:Description.maml:para: Binary path for external tools.
File with a list of computer names to process.
A list of computer names to process (comma separated).
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.
Credentials to use against remote host.
PSSession for using instead of credentials.
Method to use.
Search for a process id.
Binary path for external tools.
File with a list of computer names to process.
A list of computer names to process (comma separated).
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.

Method to use.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code:
PS> Get-Process -SearchString "p.*shell"
Time : 15.01.2017 18:05:25 Function : Get-Process ComputerName : localhost Arguments : SearchString p.*shell Status : pass Reason : {4332 ; powershell.exe ; ...

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command searches for everything with the given pattern in the process name or in the executable path.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> Invoke-PowerSponse -ComputerName comp1 -Rule dridex-201606.xml

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command reads the rule dridex-201606.xml and invokes all the corresponding functions.

maml:description.maml:para: Invoke PsExec on remote host and execute given binary with specified command line.
Invoke PsExec on remote host and execute given binary with specified command line.
`Invoke-PsExec` returns a tuple with both the PowerSponse objects and the second with the program output (exit code, stdout, stderr).

maml:Description.maml:para: Target computer.
Program to execute on remote host.
Command line used for the remote command.
Should the remote command be execute with system privileges.
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
If the binaries should be copied to the remote host. Used for e.g. autoruns execution on remote host. If flag is not used the binary must be in the path.
Force the copy to remote host.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.
Should the remote command be execute with system privileges.
Command line used for the remote command.
Target computer.
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
If the binaries should be copied to the remote host. Used for e.g. autoruns execution on remote host. If flag is not used the binary must be in the path.
Force the copy to remote host.
Program to execute on remote host.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> Invoke-PsExec -ComputerName $target -Program ipconfig -CommandLine "/all"

dev:remarks.maml:para: Start ipconifig on remote host and display output.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 2 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> $ps, $return = Invoke-PsExec -ComputerName $target -Verbose -Program ipconfig -CommandLine "/all"

dev:remarks.maml:para: `Invoke-PsExec` returns a tuple: the PowerSponse objects (pass/fail, timestamp, ...), here $ps and the exit code/stdout/stderr from the program execution, here $return.

maml:description.maml:para: Creates a new cleanup package according to the given CoRe rule.

Creates a new cleanup package according to the given CoRe rule. All functions from PowerSponse are put into one PowerShell script and all the commands from the CoRe rule are put at the end. This allows offline deployment.

maml:Description.maml:para: CoRe rule file.
A list of computer names as comma separated list.
The path where the new cleanup PowerShell script should be written to.
The filename for the new cleanup PowerShell script.
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.
{{Fill IgnoreMissing Description}}
A list of computer names as comma separated list.
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
The path where the new cleanup PowerShell script should be written to.
The filename for the new cleanup PowerShell script.
CoRe rule file.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.
{{Fill IgnoreMissing Description}}

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS> New-CleanupPackage -RuleFile .\rules\infection-2017-01-19.json Wrote cleanup script to C:\Users\user\Cleanup-74862546-8dd6-4095-88b5-693c6dbaacc9.ps1

dev:remarks.maml:para: The command creates a new cleanup package with all the required functions and cleanup commands for localhost.
